title: Looking Back to Go Forward with Marlene Fried, Loretta Ross, and Ruth Reichard

rawLines.text: American democracy is under threat and
we all need to work together to protect
the country and to protect our
democracy it's kind of like in World War
II when everyone was expected to play a
role and the first part of this is for
all of us to learn a little more and to
work together strengthening American
democracy strengthening the country the
Civic life series series is a big part
of that and the 92nd Street y New York
is the right forum for delivering all
that I appreciate your joining me
thanks welcome to the panel democracy
and Peril looking back to go forward
which is part of the Newar Newark Civic

kenady copin talks the Newark life Civic

philanthropies is known for

president and executive director of BC
voices Inc a nonprofit telling the

American women from the founding to
today facing challenges and driving
change for full equality I will be the
moderator of this illustrious panel I'm
excited to introduce you to three
fantastic women steeped in the fight for
social justice who will explore what the
history of the fight for social justice
can teach us about protecting democracy
during this time of retrenchment and
what it can tell us about the resilience
resistance and leadership we need in
this moment marleene Gerber freed a
longtime Reproductive Rights activist
scholar is well known nationally and
internationally as a writer lecturer and

fund of Western

J Ross is a professor at Smith college

and gender where she teaches course
courses on white supremacy human rights
and calling in the callout culture she
is also a recipient of a MacArthur
fellow class of 2022 for her work as an
advocate of reproductive justice and
human rights
during her career Loretta was one of the

Georgia launched the women of color

for Women and was the national program

from 2005 to
2012 she has a new book out calling in
how to start making change with those
you'd rather
cancel Ruth Reichard has worked as a
deputy prosecuting attorney in
Indianapolis Marian County and served as
a judge and Senior judge in the state of
Indiana for almost three decades where

criminal family violence cases and civil
protection order
cases after leaving full-time employment
as a judge she pivoted to Academia and
among other jobs worked as an assistant

age crisis and de

currently Ruth volunteers with the gay
men's

on my concerns is the potency of this

right I think we're GNA all going to

I come to
this panel as someone who is um a legal
professional and has been for most of my
life so I very much value the rule of
law and um understand how important it
is to our foundation as a functioning
Nation but also as a student of history
and someone who has seen change over
time and so
um the way I view it in terms of LGBT
history in particular
is the our experience of the law has
been both a sword and a
shield and once it was definitely a
sword throughout most of us history um
until the 1960s when the Civil Rights
Movement took basic human and civil
rights and through the use of the court
system uh and
Congress extended those rights to the
whole country not just the north but the
whole country and that was not
necessarily popular especially in the
South you you may be old enough to
remember watching the news and seeing
presidents send federal troops to the
South to enforce desegregation
orders but it happened because everyone
respected the rule of law and valued
order and so the LGBT movement started
using the court system as its own Shield
to get those basic human and civil

minority community and um you know so
we've gone very quickly from a situation
where to be LGBT was to be
secretive shamed
harassed subject to you know physical
violence uh not to mention job
discrimination to a world where you know
it's very difficult to be fired
especially under federal law if you're
LGBT you're able to be married you're
able to adopt children and start a
family um and so we have seen a a huge
shift and that has been
because of rights that were granted to
the LGBT community through the court
system and so the rule of law is you
know what makes us all obey the law even
though we may not like it or we may not
agree with it I mean that uh President
Eisenhower was not a fan of Brown versus
Board of
Education uh but he sent federal

that order and um you know Miranda

very

the the streets is Lawless anyway and
you know uh institutions like the New

hopefully the the innocent have some

uh for sexual minority ities and

are
definitely qu calling into question the
